JSON requests

Source: vignettes/JSON-requests.Rmd
JSON-requests.Rmd

In the following example, a table will be exported from STATcube into an R session. This process involves four steps

  • create a table with the STATcube GUI (table view)
  • download an “API request” for the table (format: *.json).
  • send the json file to the API using STATcubeR.
  • convert the return value into a data.frame

Create a table with the STATcube GUI

Use the graphical user interface of STATcube to create a table. Visit STATcube and select a database. This will open the table view where you can create a table. See the STATcube manual for details.

Download an API request

Choose “Open Data API Abfrage (.json)” in the download options. This will save a json file on your local file system.

Send the json to the API

Provide the path to the downloaded file in sc_table().

my_response <- sc_table(json_file = "path/to/api_request.json")

The object my_response contains the raw API response from httr::POST() against the /table endpoint. Printing the object will summarize the request.

(json_path <- sc_example("bev_seit_1982.json"))
#> [1] "/data/home/decill/git/STATgraph/STATcubeR/inst/json_examples/bev_seit_1982.json"
my_response <- sc_table(json_path)
my_response
#> An object of class sc_table
#> 
#> Database:      Population at the beginning of the year since 1982 
#> Measures:      Number 
#> Fields:        Time section, Bundesland, Country of birth 
#> 
#> Request:       2021-02-08 12:35:48 
#> STATcubeR:     0.1.0

Convert the response into a data frame

The return value of sc_post_json() can be converted into a data.frame using the generic function as.data.frame().

as.data.frame(my_response)

This will produce a tidy table, which contains a column for each field of the table. Furthermore, two columns will be present for each measure

as.data.frame(my_response) %>% .[c(1:4, 19:24), ]
#>    Time section           Bundesland Country of birth Number Number_a
#> 1    2020-01-01    Burgenland <AT11>          Austria 260354         
#> 2    2020-01-01    Burgenland <AT11>  Foreign country  34082         
#> 3    2020-01-01     Carinthia <AT21>          Austria 489262         
#> 4    2020-01-01     Carinthia <AT21>  Foreign country  72031         
#> 19   2020-01-01 Not classifiable <0>          Austria      0         
#> 20   2020-01-01 Not classifiable <0>  Foreign country      0         
#> 21   1982-01-01    Burgenland <AT11>          Austria     NA        X
#> 22   1982-01-01    Burgenland <AT11>  Foreign country     NA        X
#> 23   1982-01-01     Carinthia <AT21>          Austria     NA        X
#> 24   1982-01-01     Carinthia <AT21>  Foreign country     NA        X

The column Number_a contains annotations for the column Number. In order to get explanations about those annotations, use the function sc_annotation_legend().

sc_annotation_legend(my_response)
#>   annotation                                                 label
#> Q          Q STATcube – Statistical Database of STATISTICS AUSTRIA
#> X          X                           Crosstabulation not allowed

In this case, we see that row 21 contains a value NA (Not Available) because the value is not disclosed (“Crosstabulation not allowed”). However, the zero value in row 20 can be considered a “real zero value” because no annotations are provided.

Get the raw API response

To get the raw API response content, use $raw. This binding returns a nested list which contains data and metadata about the table.

my_content <- my_response$raw
names(my_content)
#> [1] "query"         "database"      "measures"      "fields"       
#> [5] "cubes"         "annotationMap"
my_content$measures
#> [[1]]
#> [[1]]$uri
#> [1] "str:statfn:debevstandjb:F-BEVSTANDJB:F-ISIS-1:SUM"
#> 
#> [[1]]$label
#> [1] "Number"
#> 
#> [[1]]$measure
#> [1] "str:measure:debevstandjb:F-BEVSTANDJB:F-ISIS-1"
#> 
#> [[1]]$`function`
#> [1] "SUM"
